review_title: the good far outweighs the bad
job_title: Behavior Health Specialist in Aurora, CO
pros: Ironically, management was great. I even loved my coworkers for the majority of the time I was here, it was the way that management happened to interact with my coworkers, and my coworkers could interact with each other that posed an issue.
cons: It started to feel very "high-school"-like for lack of a better way to explain it. Drama filled over the pettiest of things that DID NOT need to go to a management level (which I believe put my managers in a tough spot). The process was not streamlined and we were in the process of working out a new system (with 1-to-1s) so I think it became too messy for my liking. Overall, a wonderful experience though! I learned so much here.

job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Aurora, CO
pros: There are some really great individuals and teammates that work outside of the respiratory department.
cons: The respiratory department has had terrible leaders, and although significant changes were made in early 2023, the leaders are still terrible. The culture within the department does not match that of other departments/fields and they do not meet the standards of the profession. They often act on their own, not listening to other leaders, staff or follow what is common within the field. They fired one of the most influential and best leaders within the whole country, because a person lied, and never filled the role. The temporary director literally does nothing, and let’s the whole team run wild and act independently. There’s nobody running the show, and with mostly travelers on staff… they continue a pattern of being one of the worst departments in the Rocky Mountain region. They cannot keep staff for a reason, the terrible leaders and culture they continue to allow. Good therapists do not stay for a reason. Good luck ever having physicians listen to a therapist! With most having only an associates degree from a technical college, the respect will never come.

job_title: Lab Operations Manager in Aurora, CO
pros: Incredible organization that places child health and experience at the center of every decision. I would never take my kids anywhere else if they needed care, Children's Hospital Colorado employs the best of the best. Their Laboratory especially, is one of the best in the world and will bend over backwards to make miracles happen for the kids.
cons: They expect you to work yourself into the ground and sacrifice everything for the kids. Saying no is not an option. Yes is the only acceptable response, and all projects must result in a yes, even when they seem impossible or too expensive. If you are prepared for this as a calling, then you will feel proud to be a part of the journey, but it can be mentally exhausting. Because of this, there is a high level of micromanagement happening at all levels. I had employees thar were comfortable with and even conditioned to yell, yelling at their employees often if they made even the smallest mistake. The culture there is striving to be perfect, anything less is not acceptable.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: Amazing procedures, resources and care provided for patients.

After almost 7 years of struggling and working 2 jobs and picking up extra shifts, I decided I needed to move on so I could work to live and not live to work. review_title: Mediocre pay but rewarding work and talking down to this place gratitude often expressed by administration
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Aurora, CO
pros: Gratitude often expressed by administration via email and occasionally by providing food and treats to all staff. Annual bonus given on typical years if organization wide goals are met. This ranges from about 1,000 to $1,200 a year. 403b plan matched at 6% after a significant vesting period. It is very rewarding to help children. I have stayed at this hospital for this long strictly for that reason.
cons: Current staffing shortages make for challenging and exhausting shifts, especially for "market value" wages (a.k.a. bare minimum pay). Market analysis is utilized to determine pay, except when demand for labor is high and pay would otherwise reflect that . Hospital maintains and will utilize ability to schedule you to work anytime you are needed (per policy) especially if you need more than an allotted amount of time off. As a parent, I find it challenging to meet the schedule demands of the hospital and raise a family at the same time. Good luck getting vacation days granted, especially around holidays (even if they are not required). Overall employees could be treated better and paid better, but it's not the worst hospital to work at by any means.

review_title: My best nursing experience to date after 15 years in the profession.
job_title: RN in Aurora, CO
pros: Unique and complex learning experiences in one of the top rated hospitals in the nation.  Many educational opportunities.The nursing staff and management are supportive.  Training for new grads is superior with several months and levels of experience provided.  Children's offers many opportunities for personal ownership of one's nursing practice.  Staffing is usually pretty good and allows for time to spend educating and interacting with families.  Interdisciplinary collaboration is generally respected and physicians, nurses, physical therapists and other health professionals work well together and seem to value each others' experience and knowledge.  Overall, Children's Hospital has provided me with my most positive nursing experience after 15 years in the profession.
cons: The new facility is out of the way and quite a commute for many employees.  Inservices and competencies often require nurses to come in on their day off.  Especially for those working the night shift, this can be extremely inconvenient, requiring one to give up sleep in order to make the commute in to 'learn' things that are often extremely basic and redundant and could be taught via the internet or at the bedside during a nurse's regular shift.  Office politics and low morale have been an increasingly negative issue since the move to the new hospital.  Office politics and popularity contests seem to have even influenced internal promotions, leading to the best and most loyal candidates being overlooked at times.

job_title: Senior Vice President of Human Resources in Aurora, CO
pros: Compelling organizational mission, vision, values.  Academic affiliation, strong national reputation, leading patient outcomes, ethical and wise leadership, commitment to achieving the highest quality of care possible through continuous improvement, high-performing teams, development of individual potential, safe and healthy workplace, and family-friendly culture.  We have a state-of-the art hospital complex on the Anschutz Medical Campus that is only 10-years old, in addition to a new hospital in our southern Metropolitan region that is less than 5-years old.  We are building a new hospital complex in Colorado Springs that will open by mid-2019 to serve the children of southern Colorado.  This is a challenging and very rewarding place to work.  I am an executive with a significant clinical background and have steadily advanced my career here over a 26-year period.  A colleague said it best, "This is where you come to do the best, most rewarding and innovative work of your career."
cons: Not a con, per say, but downward pressure on financial margins created as a result of health care reform efforts at the national and state level threaten our mission to improve the health of children.  We care for a disproportionate share of kids from a seven-state region who qualify for means-tested insurance benefits (Medicaid).  Depending on what happens at the state and federal level, there is ambiguity about the extent of uncompensated care possible, and that is a threat to our mission and all we stand for.

review_title: Safety is slipping, inpatient RN review
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Aurora, CO
pros:
Wonderful 401k and matching, close access to retirement supervisor on site and a phone call away. Wendy is amazing. 
Wellness incentive for non-smokers. 
My experience with managers is that they work with you and other staff members to be flexible with time off.
Wonderful co-workers.
cons:
The most important thing at hospitals is safety. Over the last two years, I have felt strongly that staffing has been pulled too thin. It is very difficult to double check all orders and special protocols, help other staff, and attend to patients' and families' needs. 
It is also difficult to get more than one 20 minute break through out an entire 12-14 hour shift.

The Clinical ladder and pay scale isn't based on experience or clinical skills. It is based off of working on silly, mirco-managed projects on your free time. Committees are also an important part of this, which tend to be inconvenient for nurses whom live far away, have child care needs, or work the night shift. 
New grads no longer receive a pay bump ofter orientation. "Due to 600 applicants for 1 job opening, Childrens no longer need to be competitive in pay."

job_title: Operations Manager in Aurora, CO
pros: It's a non-profit children's hospital, rated in the top 10 in the nation year after year by US News and World Report.   The culture there is every job is meaningful because every employee is contributing to healing kids. Good pay and benefits, in this day and age, both for full-time and 1/2 time.  Many patients grow up and work there.  Many former employees come back after moving to other hospitals or industry, thus the people who work there want to work there.  Vitality Wellness Program give employees the opportunity to reduce their annual health insurance contribution byv $600.
cons: Non-profits don't pay as much as for-profits and industry.  Leadership can be slow to respond to employee's desires, but they usually do or at least find a compromise in the end.

job_title: MT1 in Aurora, CO
pros: Lots of PTO, very affordable and good health insurance, awesome 403B matching. Some departments are great to work with.  The work done at this hospital is top notch. Cutting edge research and technology is saving lots and lots of kids.
cons: No communication between different departments. Clinical Lab managers are not friendly; brush you and your concerns off, can be very rude and condescending. To be honest, most of the clinical lab staff are pretty rude and unhelpful; very clique-y. Basically no real training for any length of time, but you will be blamed when you make a mistake that you were never trained not to make. Clinical lab severely understaffed which contributes to the above problems.  Pay could be more competitive with the rest of Denver and will have to be raised due to the high cost of living here, or employees will leave.

review_title: Once Excellent Employer, Slipping a Little Unfortunately
job_title: Project Manager II in Aurora, CO
pros: Children's is just that all about children,  I see the meaning in my job every day.  The work I do is challenging and the people I work with are excellent.  Salaries are good but not increasing in pace with the industry.  Benefits are excellent.
cons: Children's is going through a major management and philosophy change and not for the better.  Currently there is a convoluted not well communicated plan to save money and the first targets were our care staff, the front line of our business.  Senior leadership continues to want to be involved in every decision yet the Children's network is too large and the leadership is over extended and not effective because of it.  Decision by committee is slowing down our organization and meetings are the bane of everyone's existence.  Children's could benefit by defining the decision making process and streamlining it.  Work/life balance used to be good but it's getting worse as empty positions are not filled.

job_title: Patient Family Service Specialist in Aurora, CO
pros: Wonderful mission. Can be very rewarding. Annual market evaluations for job titles so pay can remain competitive, but I would imagine they may pause that for 2021.
cons:
You are replaceable, especially if you are non-clinical. 

COVID-19 has made the organization show what really matters, it’s bottom line. Many benefits pulled. No tuition reimbursement after Spring semester, retirement match suspended, no raises this year, no bonuses next year.

The icing on the cake: PTO accrual for non-clinical staff members suspended while Exempt staff is forced To use PTO. Non-exempt staff is being sent home, trying to force the use of PTO. Managers and HR know exactly how many of your hours to cut so that you can’t qualify for unemployment and are trying to force those that have more PTO banked to use it by targeting them for max hours reduction. All of this while not accruing PTO, adding insult to injury.

Hours reductions in some areas are unsafe for patient care and highly stressful for staff.

review_title: Wish I could give Children's Hospital Colorado a zero star review
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Aurora, CO
pros: The friendships I formed while I was employed at CHC were friendships built to last a lifetime. It's no coicidence that none of us (5 in total) still work there. Helping children and families is extremely rewarding and the clinical aspect of CHC is phenomenal.
cons: The administrative aspect to Children's is negative, short-sighted, and incredibly toxic. The pay is terrible, the micro-managment ruins any type of innovation, growth and evolvement. Having worked in marketing I was initially excited about promoting positive messages to the community about an outstanding organization. After having been there for several years, I would not recommend this employer to anyone. My manager in particular was a bully, extremely negative, put me down on a regular basis and had terrible communication skills. They also paid me next to nothing. I went on to work for a competitor and made twice the income and now have a wonderful boss who appreciates me every day. Steer clear of Children's Hospital Colorado's marketing team. There will be no growth and the politics will wear you down.

review_title: Awesome Place to Work and Serve Others at the Same Time
job_title: Information Technologies in Aurora, CO
pros: Although we are still a business that has to remain profitable, we always remain focused on our true mission of helping kids at the same time.  Many of our employees and volunteers have their own private reasons for coming to Children's which often includes having our own children that we're helped or even saved by those that were here and willing to serve others.  The opportunities for advancement have always been amazing and it has opened my eyes to careers that I've never even considered before.
cons: Sometimes, we struggle with a work-life balance because we are now being asked, especially by our government, to do a lot more with less.  Many of the perks that we once had available are no longer available.

job_title: Corporate Offices in Aurora, CO
pros: We used to be a great place to work because we once focused on the kids, the mission, the employees and our relationships with each other. Those days are long gone. Our culture was replaced with a strong corporate attitude mixed in with a bit of socialism. Pay everyone the same and take away the incentives to achieve so the leaders can rule and the sheep can follow.
cons: Politics, poor leadership, bad attitudes, petty arguments, lack of trust, broken promises to employees, removal of career ladder changes and now we are looking at even more cutbacks.  A leader makes decisions to cut expenses but then gets a larger bonus for saving the company money. I guess that doesn't really make us a non profit any more.

review_title: All Health Care should be Not-For-Profit
job_title: Clinical Applications Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: Great focus on families, including the flexibility to work around my family's needs.  Awesome team, fun people who work hard.  Phenomenal patient care!
cons: Growth is always hard.  As the organization continues to grow, I know that they try to keep employees at the forefront, but sometimes things get miscommunicated, misinterpreted, or applied poorly.  This happens a lot, but if you just roll with the punches and focus on the fantastic patient care, you will get through it!  Sometimes you have to get creative with your professional growth, since it sometimes requires changing jobs, changing departments, etc.  There are not clear cut 'paths' in all areas.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Aurora, CO
pros: The hospital's goals are admirable.  They provide a lot of training.
cons: The workday for M-F salaried staff is 8:00 to 5:00, but most of the time we are too busy to take a lunch break or leave till 6 or 7 pm; then they schedule meetings to start at 7:30 or 7:00.  Meetings and emails take up too much of the work week, and they acknowledge all this but they are just happy to get people to work more for no extra money.  Managers are not being replaced when they leave their positions, and everyone is simply expected to do more with less.  In their attempt to slash the budget ("resource stewardship"), they are reducing many benefits and expect that staff will stay because of the hospital's reputation and their difficult hiring processes that give the impression that they are selective.

job_title: in Denver, CO
pros: Mostly friendly. Decisions are consensus driven and respectful. Pay is pretty good. Recent management replacement may be sign that organization is moving in right direction if not there yet. Easy to be proud of job that (indirectly) helps sick children. Communication about changes in organization and general news is pretty good.
cons: Overall, management is friendly and respectful, but very lacking in basic management and project management training (feedback, delegation, purpose of goals, time management, etc.). Some managers are even toxic. Fear of change stands in the way of progress. Consensus driven decisions can sometimes slow things down. Organization is not always honest with itself about how to improve. Lack of real offices means knowledge work suffers. Parking is bad but may improve soon.

review_title: It’s Different Here but not in a good way
job_title: Team Leader in Aurora, CO
pros: Pay and helping children are great. Not all departments are horrible.
cons: Condescending and absentee management that has no desire to hold negative people accountable.  Working in blood collections with the management team was a joke. Very cliquey, weak minded and supportive of a hostile environment. Accountability for the previously terminated employees from other industries goes by management waist side.  Following standards goes ignored due to a lack of training program. Blood Banking department is laughable with equipment, vehicles and complete disconnect from CHCO.

review_title: The most frustrating and disappointing place I have ever worked.

review_title: Engaging work but risk of stagnation
job_title: Marketing Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Work with some great, smart, thoughtful people in an environment that's generally respectful of your work and ideas. Director-level management is somewhat uneven, but my boss and VP are both great. Considering it's a nonprofit, the compensation and benefits are solid. And you sometimes get to do some good in the world.
cons: Lots of top-down pressure to implement last-minute ideas and projects makes it hard to work strategically. Not much will from the top to prioritize work solve persistent problems, most of them created by reactive thinking, rather than proactive planning. The hierarchy is also pretty rigid, which makes it difficult to move vertically and there's the risk of career stagnation.

job_title: in Aurora, CO
pros: Challenging environment to work in - will definitely improve your skills and you will constantly have opportunities to progress and learn more.  The C-Suite knows a lot of people under the Director level and want to have that relationship with employees.  Everyone works hard, but also plays hard.  Work-Life balance is important to my director.  Friendly, helpful coworkers - truly an enjoyable place to work!
cons: some people may find the patients to be difficult - not in and of themselves - but what they are going through can be difficult emotionally.  Howver, our leadership does a nice job of trying to offer emotional support to any employees who are having a hard time with this.

review_title: Better than a lot of places but not as great as you’d hope
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Aurora, CO
pros: Good experience, great teachers, can be very rewarding.
cons: Some people spoil it for everyone by being overly mean for no reason. Management doesn’t fire people who are burned out and make work more difficult for others. It’s very difficult to get a raise or make the same you would elsewhere in some positions as it’s so competitive to get in— they use that to their advantage. Only hire from within which can make a weird, gossipy work environment.

review_title: Loved the work and patients, toxic work environment
job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: I loved being a nurse here. I loved the patients, the education opportunities, and the mission. I feel like everyone was very educated and we all had a common goal. Pay was excellent, benefits were great.
cons: I ended up leaving (this was my dream job too) due to two reasons. Main reason, management was so toxic. They were never helpful and did not let you advance in your career. Another reason, there was no work life balance. Night shift was near impossible here due to never getting the schedule you requested, and so many requirements. I really wish it wasn’t this way. Like I said, I had to leave my dream job.

job_title: in Aurora, CO
pros: Excellent academic Children's hospital where the entire staff is dedicated to providing the best care possible for kids.  CHCO provides a lot of opportunities for staff to participate in hospital wide fun activities to keep both the patients and themselves smiling. New focus on improving staff education, compensation and communication is great!
cons: No different than anywhere else that is struggling to make the right choices to improve healthcare in our current environment.  Communication from top down challenging at best but the system seems to be putting very good effort at improving.  Decision making process a bit cumbersome and lengthy.

review_title: Wish it was a better place to work.

The have a lot of education opportunities.

review_title: Things need some revamping...for the better

cons: Salary for non-RN's is extremely poor and not at market rate at all. Other facilities compensate techs with experience, childrens does not. Even with "market rate adjustments" I as a tech with over a decade of experience was making less than a dollar more an hour than a new grad tech.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: plenty of lateral move options, switch departments, participate in committees, orient nursing students or new employees, attend educational workshops. CHCO has a huge volume of opportunity for those interested. For those who want to just show up do their jobs and not seek out the next level, that's ok too, just be sure to tell management.
cons: It's a huge hospital system which can make you feel like a cog in a huge wheel but, for those who have ambition, it's a great organization to grow within.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Aurora, CO
pros: The patients are amazing! You are truly making a difference in the lives of struggling kids.  The role can be tough but if you keep a good outlook, go above and beyond to help the new generations that are highly stressed it is a rewarding job!  I worked here for 10 years. Mostly working 3 12 hour shifts.  Overtime is offered when available in psych.
cons: Patient care is being lost in the growth.  Families are not feeling supported.  Many patients needing Mental Health are electing to go somewhere else.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Aurora, CO
pros: Great reputation, cool patients. Lots of unusual diagnoses that you wouldn't get to see at other hospitals. Gorgeous campus, good cafeteria, lots of fun things for the kids to do during the day.
cons: Lots of favoritism played. Even if you come with lots of nursing experience, expect to get the worst assignments for your first year. Some nurses were really nice and helpful, but the overall attitude of most was judgmental and condescending. Everyone seems to have this attitude of "we're CHCO, we're the best, we couldn't possibly learn anything from anyone." Though I was never personally bullied, I know many nurses who were. Everyone talks behind each other's back and you have to "prove yourself" over and over. There's very little work-life balance. You are constantly having to come in outside of work for meetings, classes and lectures. They'll move you on the schedule without asking (I know night shift nurses who would get moved to working every other day....if you work nights, you know how exhausting and terrible that is) and the weekend requirement turned out to be WAY more in reality than what I was told on my interview. My manager was almost non-existent. I literally spoke to her ONE time my entire employment.  A lot of the equipment is also weirdly antiquated. I've worked for much poorer hospitals that had way nicer materials. They also very rarely offer bonuses for people picking up extra, even if we were dangerously short staffed. I think Children's is just more interested in spending money on their image than their staff. Overall it was a very arrogant and corporate environment that drained me of all energy.

job_title: Administrative in Aurora, CO
pros: People want to work here, and are happy to be associated with the hospital. Good benefits and overall great environment provided to employees by upper management.
cons: Experience working here really depends on what department you are in. Very toxic inpatient departments, with management that offer jobs to family members and friends. Can go months without interacting with direct manager. Once you move to a better run department it’s a totally different world!

review_title: Look elsewhere for an RN job
job_title: Registered Nurse CNIII in Aurora, CO
pros:
Make my own schedule
24/7 cafeteria
Dog visits with the pet prescription program
Volunteer opportunities 
Decent Health Insurance offerings
Beautiful facility
cons:
Definite separation between the medical side of the hospital and management side.
All shift differentials have either been reduced or discontinued all together.
The nursing clinical ladder has been frozen. No current chance for RN's to advance from the bedside. 
Management discontinuing Clinical Coordinator-Charge Nurse roles. Not offering to relocate these experienced RN's, only offering severance packages.
New staffing model being implemented. More CA's and LPN's doing patient cares, less RN interaction. "Nursing Home" staffing model is the base model.
The patients acuitity level (how sick they are) not being considered in the new staffing model (RN's daily assignments) only RN/CNA ratio being considered, therefore making many unsafe daily/nightly assignments.
Patient/Family satisfaction decreasing as staffing model changes. Less RN presence/interaction at the bedside.
Management not listening to RN's concerns of unsafe assignments being made. Many experienced RN's looking for employment elsewhere.
Traveler nurses being hired instead of management working on retention of current RN's.
